result.markdown:
--- title: Scapulothoracic Joint subtitle: Pseudo-Joint of the shoulder girdle --- There are 6 primary movements of the scapulothoracic joint: 1. [Elevation](#elevation) and [Depression](#depression) 1. [Protraction](#protraction) and [Retraction](#retraction) 1. [Upward](#upward-rotation) and [Downward rotation](#downward-rotation) # Alignment - Vertebral border - Parallel to spine, 2-3 finger width (3’’) from the midline of the thorax - Between 2nd and 7th thoracic vertebrae - 30° ant to the frontal plane (scapular plane) - 10° ant tilt - 5-10° upward rotation # Elevation & Depression ## Elevation {#elevation} Elevation refers to when the scapula slides superiorly relative to the thorax @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. Shrugging the shoulders is an example of scapular elevation @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The scapulothoracic joint as 40° of elevation @jonesProjectFoundations2025. - Includes elevation of clavicle at SC and downward rot of scap at AC Elevation is created by coactivation of the *upward rotators* along with the [levator scapulae]({{< var ref-levator-scapulae.action >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. The activation of the upward rotators brings the acromion (lateral) aspect of the scapula superomedially, but the [levator scapulae]({{< var ref-levator-scapulae.action >}}) counteracts the rotation to create pure **scapular elevation** @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ## Depression Depression of the scapulothoracic joint refers to when the scapula slides inferiorly relative to the thorax from an elevated position @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The scapulothoracic joint is capable of 10° of depression @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Protraction & Retraction ## Protraction {#protraction} *Protraction* refers to when the [medial border of the scapula]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.medial-border >}}) slides anterolaterally relative to the thorax @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. This will result in movement of the [medial border]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.medial-border >}}) *away* from the spine. An example of protraction is when you are reaching forward as far as possible @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The scapulothoracic joint is capable of 20° of protraction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. Protraction requires a combination of the [serratus anterior]({{< var ref-serratus-anterior.action >}}) and [pec minor]({{< var ref-pectoralis-minor.action >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: {#tbl-scapulothoracic-protractors-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Scapulothoracic Protractors' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Pectoralis minor 3-5 ribs Coracoid process Medial pectoral n.
C8 - T1		 Scapula: Depression, Downward rotation, Protraction
Respiration: Assists in respiration
Serratus anterior 1-9 Ribs Superior angle of Scapula (costal and dorsal surfaces)
Medial border of scapula (costal surface)
Medial border of scapula (costal surface)
Inferior angle of Scapula (costal & dorsal surfaces)		 Long thoracic n.
C5 - C7		 Superior part: Lowers raised arm
Entire mm.: Protraction, Rib elevation (with fixed shoulder)
Inferior part: Rotates scapula laterally forward
``` ::: ::: ## Retraction {#retraction} Scapular *retraction* refers to when the [medial border of the scapula]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.medial-border >}}) slides posteromedially relative to the thorax *towards* the midline @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. This is exemplified when you "pinch" the shoulder blades together. The scapulothoracic joint is capable of 15° of retraction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. Retraction is produced through contraction of [middle trap]({{< var ref-middle-trapezius.action >}}) and [lower trap]({{< var ref-lower-trapezius.action >}}) with assistance of [rhomboid major]({{< var ref-rhomboid-major.action >}}) and [minor]({{< var ref-rhomboid-minor.action >}}) @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: {#tbl-scapulothoracic-retractors-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Scapulothoracic Retractors' execution_count=2} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Lower trapezius T5-T12 SP Scapular spine Accessory n. (CN XI)
C3 - C4		 Scapula: Retraction, Depression, Upward rotation, Stabilizes scapula on thorax
Middle trapezius Aponeurosis of T1-T4 SP Acromion Accessory n. (CN XI)
C3 - C4		 Scapula: Retraction
Rhomboid major T1-T4 SP Medial border of scapula (below scapular spine) Dorsal scapular n.
C4 - C5		 Scapula: Retraction assist, Downward rotation, Stabilization
Rhomboid minor C6 & C7 SP Medial border of scapula (above scapular spine) Dorsal scapular n.
C4 - C5		 Scapula: Retraction assist, Downward rotation, Stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Upward & Downward rotation Upward and downward rotation of the scapula refers to scapular movement in the frontal plane. ## Upward Rotation {#upward-rotation} During scapular *upward rotation*, the [inferior angle of the scapula]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.inferior-angle >}}) *rotates* superiolaterally relative to the thorax @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 This results in the [glenoid fossa]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.glenoid-fossa >}}) facing upwards @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. Upward rotation is a key component when raising the arm upward @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The scapulothoracic joint is capable of 60° of upward rotation @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: {#tbl-scapulothoracic-upward-rotators-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Scapulothoracic Upward Rotators' execution_count=3} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Lower trapezius T5-T12 SP Scapular spine Accessory n. (CN XI)
C3 - C4		 Scapula: Retraction, Depression, Upward rotation, Stabilizes scapula on thorax
Serratus anterior 1-9 Ribs Superior angle of Scapula (costal and dorsal surfaces)
Medial border of scapula (costal surface)
Medial border of scapula (costal surface)
Inferior angle of Scapula (costal & dorsal surfaces)		 Long thoracic n.
C5 - C7		 Superior part: Lowers raised arm
Entire mm.: Protraction, Rib elevation (with fixed shoulder)
Inferior part: Rotates scapula laterally forward
Upper trapezius Occiput
SP C1-C7		 lateral 1/3 of Clavicle Accessory n. (CN XI)
C3 - C4		 Scapula: Elevation, Upward rotatino
Neck: I/L sidebend, C/L Rotation
``` ::: ::: ## Downward rotation {#downward-rotation} Downward rotation refers to when the [inferior angle of the scapula]({{< var ref-scapula-bone.inferior-angle >}}) *rotates* in an inferomedially direction @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. Downward rotation is most obvious when *lowering* the scapula from an upwardly rotated position @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The scapulothoracic joint is capable of 30° of downward rotation @jonesProjectFoundations2025. *Downward rotation* is key component of lowering the arm down to one's side @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. ::: {#tbl-scapulothoracic-downward-rotators-oian .cell message='false' tbl-cap='Scapulothoracic Downward Rotators' execution_count=4} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Warning: No 'action' link found for variable 'ref-rhomboid-minor' in YAML data. ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} Although the [subclavius]({{< var ref-subclavius.action >}}) does not directly insert on the scapula, it indirectly depresses the shoulder girdle by depressing the clavicle @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: # Anterior & Posterior Tilting ## Anterior Tilt ## Posterior Tilt 20° post tilt during arm elevation # Kinematics ### Force couple - Serratus anterior (greatest mechanical advantage for UR) - Upper trap (Initiation and throughout) - Late phase: Lower trap ## Internal Rotation <= 5° IR/ER ## External Rotation <= 5° # Stabilization The Serratus Anterior (along with the rhomboids) serves to aid in scapular stability during arm elevation @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020 ![Superior View of the shoulder: You can see how the rhomboids and SA both actively stabilize the scapulothoracic joint by pulling the scapula towards the thoracic wall @duttonDuttonOrthopaedicExamination2020](/The Archive/Anatomy/Skeletal Muscles/Upper Limb Muscles/Axioappendicular Posterior Muscles/images/Dutton fig16.2 Superior aspect of shoulder.png) ### Stabilization - Middle trap (add / retract) which counteract the protraction force of the Serratus anterior, resulting in stabilization of the scapula # Dysfunction - Scapular winging
